My full statement ‚¨áÔ∏è http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FxidAWtWwAMhUIT.png

Runaway spending and a supercharged administrative state are grave threats to our country, and I look forward to working with my colleagues to reduce spending, enact structural reforms, and return power back to the people.
This is an important moment for our country, as we have the opportunity to rein in spending and enact much-needed structural reform -- unfortunately the Fiscal Responsibility Act does neither.
For far too long, Washington has refused to run our government as families in Missouri do: balanced budgets, sound finances, and living within your means.

Missourians didn‚Äôt send me here to support the status quo, they sent me here to fight for change and to fight for fiscal sanity. 

In its current form, I cannot support the Fiscal Responsibility Act, and will vote against it.
This is an important moment for our country, as we have the opportunity to rein in spending and enact much-needed structural reform -- unfortunately the Fiscal Responsibility Act does neither.
For far too long, Washington has refused to run our government as families in Missouri do: balanced budgets, sound finances, and living within your means.

I am supporting this bipartisan deal because that‚Äôs what‚Äôs best for Georgians. I hope my colleagues on both sides of the aisle join me. (6/6)

I‚Äôm also glad that this bill will ensure the neediest Georgians and Americans‚Äîlike our veterans, foster youth, and the housing insecure‚Äîmaintain access to critical benefits that help make sure they have food on the table, clothes on their backs and a roof over their heads. (5/6)

But I‚Äôm glad that cooler heads prevailed and crafted a bipartisan bill that will allow us to pay our bills and avoid a default, while also preserving important investments that help hardworking Georgia families and keep our economy strong. (4/6)
It‚Äôs shameful that partisan actors and their political brinkmanship needlessly pushed us toward a potential default in the first place, using poor people as pawns. (3/6)
Avoiding a default is the top priority right now because defaulting on our debt would be detrimental to Georgia‚Äôs families, Main Street, and the rest of our economy. (2/6)

This legislation represents just the start of the changes we need in Washington. 

With over $31 trillion in national debt ‚Äì larger than our entire economy ‚Äì much more hard work awaits us to prevent future bankruptcy.
It claws back unspent COVID money and slashes funding to the IRS for more agents, both byproducts of an unchecked radical Democrat majority.

Most importantly, the Fiscal Responsibility Act does NOT result in new taxes that President Biden wanted and does NOT touch Social Security, Medicare, or veterans‚Äô benefits. It actually increases our nation‚Äôs investment in our veterans.

It creates a pathway out of poverty for Americans by reforming work requirements for welfare programs. 

It also streamlines our onerous permitting system so America can once again develop its own energy resources and build long overdue infrastructure in a timely manner.
It reins in dictatorial Executive Branch spending by enacting the first ever statutory administrative PAYGO, thus preventing Biden from spending billions via regulatory edict.

The bill forces Congress to have a true functioning appropriations process, and if for two years any Congress were to not adhere to these principles, it automatically imposes a spending cap until such is corrected.
This landmark legislation lowers non-defense discretionary spending, excluding veterans‚Äô benefits, to below FY 2022 levels and only allows for 1% growth for the next six years.

Last night, the House voted to pass a responsible debt limit bill that alters our fiscal trajectory and takes much needed measures to remedy the federal government's spending problem.
